history.content:
Do the discussions and read the lecture slides. Then do the labs and projects to completion (homeworks are not very useful). Finally, do some practice exams. This will ensure close to full understanding of the material.

------------------------------------------------------------
Depends on what you are trying to get out of it. It is true that getting a good grade in 61C is not really contingent on reading the textbook (Computer Organization and Design), but I believe that there's a lot of value in actually reading the book (it's a pretty good book imo) and learning the material (maybe excluding some Verilog and others random stuff). 

tldr; read the book if you're actually into computer architecture and more hardware stuff; if not, your time is probably better spent on side projects or interview prep

Do the discussions and read the lecture slides. Then do the labs and projects to completion (homeworks are not very useful). Finally, do some practice exams. This will ensure close to full understanding of the material.

I am not doing much this summer, so I am thinking about starting to for 61C already. Since I do not learn much from lectures, I was thinking about reading the text book. Unfortunately from previous experience in 61B, the text books (other than the online one) had a lot of scattered and extra content that made reading very hard. 

For people who have taken the class before, what would you recommend me do? Obviously the best way is to do the HW and projects, but I can barely those with office hours (lol).
history.subject: Self-study CS61C
